Penuria est. Homo antiquâ virtute ac fide:

Quam gaudeo, ubi etiam hujus generis reliquias

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for T. BECKET and P. A. DE HONDT, near Surry-Street, in the Strand; and R. BALDWIN, in Pater-noster-Row.
TO MONSIEUR DE VOLTAIRE THE FOLLOWING COMEDY, A TRIBUTE DUE TO THE AUTHOR OF L'ECOSSAISE, IS INSCRIBED BY HIS MOST OBEDIENT HUMBLE SERVANT, GEORGE COLMAN.

LG.L: EACH Year how many English visit France,
To learn the Language, or to learn to dance!
'Twixt Dover-Cliffs and Calais, in July,
Observe how thick the Birds of Passage fly!
Fair-Weather Fops in Swarms, fresh-water Sailors,
Cooks, Mantua-makers, Milleners, and Tailors.
Our Brd too made a Trip; and, Sland'rers say,
Brought home, among some more Run-Goods, a Play:
Here, on this Quay, prepar'd t'unload his Cargo,
If on the Freight you lay not an Embargo.
"What! am I branded for a Smuggler?" cries
Our little Bayes, with Anger in his Eyes.
"No. English Poets, English Merchants made,
"To the whole World of Letters fairly trade:
"With the rich Stores of ancient Rome and Greece,
"Imported Duty-free, may fill their Piece:
"Or, like Columbus, cross th' Atlantick Ocean,
"And set Peru and Mexico in Motion;
"Turn Cherokees and Catabaws to Shape;
"Or sail for Wit and Humour to the Cape."
Is there a Weaver here from Spital-fields?
To his Award our Author fairly yields.
The Pattern, he allows, is not quite new,
And he imports the raw Materials too.
Come whence they will, from Lyons, Genoa, Rome,
'Tis English Silk when wrought in English Loom.
Silk! he recants; and owns, with lowly Mind,
His Manufacture is a coarser Kind.
Be it Drab, Drugget, Flannel, Doyley, Friese,
Rug, or whatever Winter-wear you please,
So it have Leave to rank in any Class,
Pronounce it English Stuff, and let it pass!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE A room in Mrs. Goodman's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: BE quiet, Mr. Spatter! let me alone! Pray now, Sir! It is a strange thing a body can't go about the house without being pester'd with your impertinence—Why sure!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Introduce me to your mistress then—come, there's a good girl!—and I will teaze you no longer▪

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Indeed I shan't—Introduce you to my lady! for what, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Oh! for a thousand things. To laugh, to chat, to take a dish of tea, to—

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: You drink tea with my lady! I should not have thought of that—On what acquaintance?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: The most agreeable in the world, child! a new acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Indeed you mistake yourself mightily—you are not a proper acquaintance for a person of her quality, I assure you, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Why, what quality is she, then?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Much too high quality for your ac∣quaintance, I promise you. What! a poet-man! that sits write, write, write, all day long, scribbling a pack of nonsense for the news-papers!—You're fit for nothing above a chambermaid.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: That's as much as to say, that you think me just fit for you. Eh, child!

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: No, indeed, not I, Sir. Neither my lady nor I will have any thing to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Your mistress and you both give your∣selves a great many airs, my dear. Your poverty, I think, might pull down your pride.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: What does the fellow mean by poverty?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I mean that you are starving.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Oh the slanderous monster! We! Starv∣ing! Who told you so? I'd have you to know, Sir, my-lady-has a very great fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: So 'tis a sign, by her way of life and ap∣pearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Well; she lives privately, indeed, be∣cause she loves retirement; she goes plain, be∣cause she hates dress; she keeps no table, because she is an enemy to luxury.—In short, my lady is as rich as a Jew, and you are an impertinent cox∣comb.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Come, come! I know more of your mistress than you imagine.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: And what do you know of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Oh, I know what I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Well! [alarme.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I know who she is, and where she came from; I am very well acquainted with her family, and know her whole history.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: How can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P:
Very easily—I have correspondence every where. As private as she may think herself, it is
not the first time that I have seen or heard of Amelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Oh gracious! as sure as I am alive this man will discover us. [apart.] Mr. Spatter, my dear Mr. Spatter, if you know any thing, sure you would not be so cruel as to betray us!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: My dear Mr. Spatter! O ho! I have guess'd right—there is something then.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: No, Sir, there is nothing at all; nothing that signifies to you or any body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Well, well, I'll say nothing; but then you must—

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Come; kiss me, hussy!

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I say kiss you, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: And you'll introduce me to your mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Not I, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Nay, no mysteries between you and me, child! Come; here's the key to all locks, the clue to every maze, and the discloser of all se∣crets; money, child! Here! take this purse; you see I know something; tell me the rest, and I have the fellow to it in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! poor Mr. Spatter! Where could you get all this money, I wonder! Not by your poetries, I believe. But what signifies tel∣ling you any thing, when you are acquainted with our whole history already? You have correspon∣dence every where, you know. There, Sir! take up your filthy purse again, and remember that I scorn to be obliged to any body but my mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: There's impudence for you! when to my certain knowledge your mistress has not a guinea in the world; you live in continual fear of being discovered; and you will both be utterly undone in a fortnight, unless Lord Falbridge should pre∣vent it, by taking Amelia under his protection. You understand me, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: You scandalous wretch! Did you ever hear such a monster? I won't stay a moment longer with him—But you are quite mistaken about me and my mistress, I assure you, Sir. We are in the best circumstances in the world; we have nothing to fear; and we don't care a far∣thing for you.—So your servant, Mr. Poet! [Exit.

DIV2.P: Your servant, Mrs. Pert! “We are in the best circumstances in the world.” Ay, that is as much as to say, they are in the utmost distress. "We have nothing to fear."—That is, they are frightened out of their wits.—“And we don't care a farthing for you.”—Meaning, that they will take all the care in their power, that I shall not find them out.—But I may be too hard for you yet, young gentlewoman! I have earned but a poor livelihood by mere scandal and abuse; but if I could once arrive at doing a little substantial mis∣chief, I should make my fortune.
Oh! your servant, Mrs. Goodman! Your's is the most unsociable lodging-house in town. So many ladies, and only one gentleman! and you won't take the least notice of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: How so, Mr. Spatter?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Why, did not you promise to introduce me to Amelia?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: To tell you the plain truth, Mr. Spatter, she don't like you. And, indeed, I don't know how it is, but you make yourself a great many enemies.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Yes; I believe I do raise a little envy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Indeed y re mistaken, Sir. As you are a lodger of mine, it makes me quite un∣easy to hear what the world says of you. How do you contrive to make so many enemies, Mr. Spatter?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Because I have merit, Mrs. Goodman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: May be so; but nobody will allow it but yourself. They say that you set up for a wit, indeed; but that you deal in nothing but scandal, and think of nothing but mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I do speak ill of the men sometimes, to be sure; but then I have a great regard for wo∣men—provided they are handsome: and that I may give you a proof of it, introduce me to Amelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: You must excuse me; she and you would be the worst company in the world; for she never speaks too well of herself, nor the least ill of any body else. And then her virtue—

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Pooh, pooh, she speaks ill of nobody, because she knows nobody; and as for her virtue, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: You don't believe much in that, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I have not over-much faith, Mrs. Good∣man. Lord Falbridge, perhaps, may give a bet∣ter account of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Lord Falbridge can say nothing but what would be extremely to her honour, I assure you, Sir. [Spatter laughs.] Well, well, you may laugh, but it is very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P:
Oh, I don't doubt it; but you don't tell the whole truth, Mrs. Goodman. When any of your friends or acquaintance sit for their pictures, you draw a very flattering likeness. All charac∣ters have their dark side, and if they have but one eye, you give them in profile. Your great friend,
Mr. Freeport, for instan whom you are always praising for his benevolent actions—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: He is benevolence itself, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Yes, and grossness itself too. I remember him these many years. He always cancels an ob∣ligation by the manner of conferring it; and does you a favour, as if he were going to knock you down.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: A truce with your satire, good M. Spatter! Mr. Freeport is my best friend; I owe him every thing; and I can't endure the slightest reflection on his character. Besides, he can have given no offence to Lady Alton, whatever may be the case with Amelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Lady Alton! she is a particular friend of mine to be sure; but between you and me, Mrs. Goodman, a more ridiculous character than any you have mentioned. A bel esprit forsooth! and as vain of her beauty as learning, without any great portion of either. A fourth Grace, and a tenth Muse! who fancies herself enamour'd of Lord Falbridge, because she would be proud of such a conquest; and has lately bestowed some marks of distinction on me, because she thinks it will give her credit among persons of letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Nay, if you can't spare your own friends, I don't wonder at your attacking mine—and so, Sir, your humble servant.—But stay! here's a post-chaise stopp'd at our door; and here comes a servant with a portmanteau! 'Tis the gen∣tleman for whom my first floor was taken, I sup∣pose.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Very likely: well, you will introduce me to him at least, Mrs. Goodman.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a servant with a portmanteau—Sir William Douglas following.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: You are Mrs. Goodman, I suppose, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G.
SP.P: At your service, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Mr. Owen, I believe, has secured apart∣ments here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G.
SP.P: He has, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. W.
SP.P: They are for me, Madam—Have you any other lodgers?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G.
SP.P: Only that gentleman, Sir; and a young lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Of great beauty and virtue. Eh, Mrs. Goodman?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G.
SP.P: She has both, Sir; but you will see very little of her, for she lives in the most retired manner in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. W.
SP.P: Her youth and beauty are matter of great indifference to me; for I shall be as much a recluse as herself.—Are there any news at present stirring in London?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G.
SP.P: Mr. Spatter can inform you, Sir, for he deals in news. In the mean while, I'll prepare your apartments. [Exit, followed by the servant.

DIV2.STAGE: Manent Sir William Douglas, and Spatter; Sir William walks up and down without taking notice of Spatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: This must be a man of quality by his ill manners. I'll speak to him [aside.] [to Sir William] Will your Lordship give me leave—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Lordship! I am no Lord, Sir, and must beg not to be honoured with the name.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: It is a kind of mistake, that cannot dis∣please at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I don't know that. None but a fool would be vain of a title, if he had one; and none but an impostor would assume a title, to which he has no right.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Oh, you're of the House of Commons then, a member of parliament, and are come up to town to attend the sessions, I suppose, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: No matter what I am, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Nay, no offence, I hope, Sir. All I meant was to do you honour. Being concerned in two evening posts and one morning-paper, I was willing to know the proper manner of announcing your arrival.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: You have connections with the press then, it seems, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; I am an humble retainer to the Muses, an author. I compose pamphlets on all subjects, compile magazines, and do news-papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Do news-papers! What do you mean by that, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: That is, Sir, I collect the articles of news from the other papers and make new ones for the postscript, translate the mails, write occasional letters from Cato and Theatricus, and give fictitious answers to supposed correspondents.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: A very ingenious as well as honourable employment, I must confess, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Some little genius is requisite, to be sure. Now, Sir, if I can be of any use to you—if you have any friend to be praised, or any enemy to be abused; any author to cry up, or minister to run down; my pen and talents are entirely at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P:
I am much obliged to you, Sir, but at present I have not the least occasion for either▪ In return for your genteel offers, give me leave to trouble you with one piece of advice▪ Whe
you deal in private scandal, have a care of the cudgel; and when you meddle with publick matters, beware of the pillory?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: How, Sir! are you no friend to litera∣ture? Are you an enemy to the liberty of the press?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I have the greatest respect for both; but railing is the disgrace of letters, and personal abuse the scandal of freedom: foul-mouthed criticks, are in general disappointed authors; and they, who are the loudest against ministers, only mean to be paid for their silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: That may be sometimes, Sir; but give me leave to ask you—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Do not ask me at present, Sir! I see a particular friend of mine coming this way, and I must beg you to withdraw!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Withdraw, Sir! first of all, allow me to—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Nay, no reply! we must be in private. [Thrusting out Spatter.] What a wretch! as con∣temptible as mischievous. Our generous mastiffs fly at men from an instinct of courage; but this fellow's attacks proceed from an instinct of base∣ness—But here comes the faithful Owen, with▪as many good qualities as that execrable fellow seems to have bad ones.

DIV2.P: Well Owen; I am safe arrived you fee.

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: Ah, Sir! would to heaven you were as safe returned again! Have a care of betraying yourself to be Sir William Douglas!—During you stay here, your name is Ford, remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P:
I shall take care—But tell me your news—What have you done since your arrival? Have you heard any thing of my daughter? Have
you seen Lord Brumpton? Has he any hope of obtaining my pardon?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: He had, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: And what can have destroyed it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: My Lord Brumpton is dead, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: I saw him within this week in apparent good health; he promised to exert his whole inte∣rest in your favour: by his own appointment I went to wait on him yesterday noon, when I was stunned with the news of his having died suddenly the evening before.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: My Lord Brumpton dead! the only friend I had remaining in England; the only per∣son, on whose intercession I relied for my pardon. Cruel fortune! I have now no hope but to find my daughter. Tell me, Owen; have you been able to hear any tidings of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: Alas, Sir, none that are satisfactory. On the death of Mr. Andrews, in whose care you left her, being cruelly abandoned by the relation who succeeded to the estate, she left the country some months ago, and has not since been heard of.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Unhappy there too! When will the measure of my misfortunes be full? When will the malice of my fate be satisfied? Proscribed, condemned, attainted, (alas, but too justly!) I have lost my rank, my estate, my wife, my son, and all my family. One only daughter remains. Perhaps a wretched wanderer like myself, perhaps in the extremest indigence, perhaps dishonoured—Ha! that thought distracts me.

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: My dear master, have patience! Do not be ingenious to torment yourself, but consult your safety, and prepare for your departure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P:
No, Owen. Hearing, providentially, of the death of my friend Andrews, paternal care and tenderness drew me hither; and I will not
quit the kingdom till I learn something of my child, my dear Amelia, whom I left a tender in∣nocent in the arms of the best of women twenty years ago. Her sex demands protection; and she is now of an age, in which she is more exposed to misfortunes than even in helpless infancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: Be advised; depart, and leave that care to me. Consider; your life is now at stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: My life has been too miserable to ren∣der me very sollicitous for its preservation—But the complection of the times is changed; the very name of the party, in which I was unhappily en∣gaged, is extinguished, and the whole nation is unanimously devoted to the throne. Disloyalty and insurrection are now no more, and the sword of justice is suffered to sleep. If I can find my child, and find her worthy of me, I will fly with her to take refuge in some foreign country; if I am discovered in the search, I have still some hopes of mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: Heaven grant your hopes may be well founded!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Come, Owen! let us behave at least with fortitude in our adversity! Follow me to my apartment, and let us consult what measures we shall take in searching for Amelia. [Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Poor Molly! to be teazed with that odi∣ous fellow, Spatter!

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: But Madam, Mr. Spatter says he is ac∣quainted with your whole history.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P:
Mere pretence, in order to render himself formidable. Be on your guard against him, my dear Molly; and remember to conceal my misery
from him and all the world. I can bear poverty▪ but am not proof against insult and contempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Ah, my dear mistress, it is to no pur∣pose to endeavour to hide it from the world. They will see poverty in my looks. As for you, you can live upon the air; the greatness of your soul seems to support you; but lack-a-day, I shall grow thinner and thinner every day of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: I can support my own distress, but yours touches me to the soul. Poor Polly! the labour of my hands shall feed and cloath you—Here! dispose of this embroidery to the best advantage; what was formerly my amusement, must now be∣come the means of our subsistence. Let us be obliged to nobody, but owe our support to in∣dustry and virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: You're an angel: let me kiss those dear hands that have worked this precious embroidery; let me bathe them with my tears! You're an angel upon earth. I had rather starve in your service, than live with a princess. What can I do to com∣fort you?

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Thou faithful creature—only continue to be secret: you know my real character; you know I am in the utmost distress: I have opened my heart to you, but you will plant a dagger there if you betray me to the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Ah, my dear mistress, how should I be∣tray you! I go no where, I converse with nobody but yourself and Mrs. Goodman: besides, the world is very indifferent about other people's mis¦fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: The world is indifferent, it is true; but it is curious, and takes a cruel pleasure in tearing open the wounds of the unfortunate. [Enter Mrs. Goodman.] Mrs. Goodman!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P:
Excuse me, Madam: I took the l∣berty of waiting on you to receive your command
'Tis now near three o'clock. You have provided nothing for dinner, and have scarce taken any re∣freshment these three days.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: I have been indisposed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: I am afraid you are more than in∣disposed—You are unhappy—Pardon me! but I cannot help thinking that your fortune is unequal to your appearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Why should you think so? You never heard me complain of my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: No, but I have too much reason to believe it is inferior to your merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Indeed, you flatter me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Come, come; you must not indulge this melancholy. I have a new lodger, an elderly gentleman, just arrived, who does me the honour to partake of my dinner; and I must have your company too. He seems to be in trouble, as well as you. You must meet; two persons in afflic∣tion may perhaps become a consolation to each other. Come, let us take some care of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Be assured, Mrs. Goodman, I am much obliged to you for your attention to me; but I want nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Dear Madam! you say you want nothing, and you are in want of every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: [to Mrs. Good.] Lady Alton, Madam, sends her compliments, and will wait upon you after dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P:
Very well; my best respects to her Ladyship, and I shall be ready to attnd her. [Exit Servant.] There, there is one cause of your uneasiness! Lady Alton's visit is on your account. She thinks you have robbed her of Lord Fal∣bridge's
affections, and that is the occasion of her honouring me with her company.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Lord Falbridge's affections!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Ah! my dear Amelia; you don't know your power over his heart. You have re∣conciled it to virtue—But come! let me prevail on you to come with me to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: You must excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Well, well, then I'll send you some∣thing to your own apartment. If you have any other commands, pray honour me with them, for I would fain oblige you, if I knew how it were in my power. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: What an amiable woman! If it had not been for her apparent benevolence and goodness of heart, I should have left the house on Mr. Spatter's coming to lodge in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Lady Alton▪ it seems▪ recommended him as a lodger here; so he can be no friend of yours on that account; for to be sure she owes you no good will on account of my Lord Falbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: No more of Lord Falbridge, I beseech you, Molly. How can you persist in mentioning him, when you know that, presuming on my situ∣ation, he has dared to affront me with dishonour∣able proposals?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Ah, Madam, but he sorely repents it, I promise you, and would give his whole estate for an opportunity of seeing you once more, and get∣ting into your good graces again.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: No; his ungenerous conduct has thrown him as much below me, as my condition had placed me beneath him. He imagined he had a right to insult my distress; but I will teach him to think it respectable. [Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE An apartment at Mrs. Goodman's▪

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: BUT you won't hear me, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: I have heard too much, Sir! This wandering incognita a woman of virtue! I have no patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Mrs. Goodman pretends to be convinced of her being a person of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: A person of honour, and openly receive visits from men! seduce Lord Falbridge! No, no: reserve this character for your next novel, Mr. Spatter! it is an affront to my understanding. I begin to suspect you have betrayed me; you have gone over to the adverse party, and are in the conspiracy to abuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I, Madam! Neither her beauty, nor her virtue—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Her beauty! her virtue! Why, thou wretch, thou grub of literature, whom I as a pa∣troness of learning and encourager of men of let∣ters, willing to blow the dead coal of genius, fondly took under my protection, do you remem∣ber what I have done for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: With the utmost gratitude, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Did not I draw you out of the garret, where you daily spun out your flimsy brain to catch the town flies in your cobweb dissertations? Did not I introduce you to Lord Dapperwit, the Apollo of the age? And did not you dedicate your silly volume of poems on several occasions to him? Did not I put you into the list of my visitors, and order my porter to admit you at dinner-time? Did not I write the only scene in your execrable farce, which the audience vouchsafed an hearing? And did not my female friend, Mrs. Melpomene, fur∣nish you with Greek and Latin mottoes for your twopenny essays?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I acknowledge all your Ladyship's good∣ness to me. I have done every thing in my power to shew my gratitude, and fulfill your Ladyship's commands.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Words, words, Mr. Spatter! You have been witness of Lord Falbridge's inconstancy. A perfidious man! False as Phaon to Sappho, or Jason to Medea! You have seen him desert me for a wretched vagabond; you have seen me aban∣doned like Calypso, without making a single ef∣fort to recall my faithless Ulysses from the Siren that has lired him from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Be calm but one moment, Madam, and I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Bid the sea be calm, when the winds are let loose upon it. I have reason to be enraged. I placed you in genteel apartments in this house, merely to plant you as a spy; and what have you done for me? Have you employed your corre∣spondence to any purpose? or discovered the real character of this infamous woman, this insolent Amelia?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P:
I have taken every possible method to de∣tect her. I have watched Amelia herself like a ailiff, or a Duenna; I have overheard private
conversations; have sounded the landlady; tam∣pered with the servants; opened letters; and in∣tercepted messages.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Good creature! my best Spatter! And what? what have you discovered?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: That Amelia is a native of Scotland; that her surname Walton is probably not real, but as∣sumed; and that she earnestly wishes to conceal both the place of her birth and her family.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: And is that all?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: All that I have been able to learn as yet, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Wretch! of what service have you been then? Are these your boasted talents? When we want to unravel an ambiguous character, you have made out that she wishes to lie concealed; and when we wish to know who she is, you have just discovered that she is a native of Scotland.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: And yet if you will give me leave, Ma∣dam, I think I could convince you that these dis∣coveries, blind and unsatisfactory as they may ap∣pear to you at first, are of no small consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Of what consequence can they possibly be to me, man?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I'll tell you, Madam. It is a rule in po∣liticks, when we discover something, to add some∣thing more. Something added to something, makes a good deal; upon this basis I have formed a syl∣logism.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: What does the pedant mean? A syllo∣gism!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Yes, a syllogism: as for example; Any person who is a native of Scotland, and wishes to be concealed, must be an enemy to the govern∣ment. Amelia is a native of Scotland, and wishes to be concealed. Ergo, Amelia is an enemy to the government.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Excellent! admirable logick! but I wish we could prove it to be truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I would not lay a wager of the truth of it; but I would swear it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: What, on a proper occasion, and in 2 proper place, my good Spatter?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Willingly; we must make use of what we know, and even of what we don't know. Truth is of a dry and simple nature, and stands in need of some little ornament. A lie, indeed, is infa∣mous; but fiction, your Ladyship, who deals in poetry, knows is beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: But the substance of your fiction, Spatter?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I will lodge an information that the father of Amelia is a disaffected person, and has sent her to London for treasonable purposes: nay, I can upon occasion even suppose the father himself to be in London: in consequence of which you will probably recover Lord Falbridge, and Amelia will be committed to prison.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: You have given me new life. I took you for a mere stainer of paper; but I have found you a Machiavel.—I hear somebody coming.—Mrs. Goodman has undertaken to send Amelia hither. Ha! she's here—Away Spatter, and wait for me at my house: you must dine with me; and after dinner, like true politicians, we will settle our plan of operations over our coffee. Away, away this instant! [Exit Spatter▪

DIV2.P:
A convenient engine this Mr. Spatter: the most impudent thorough-paced knave in the three king∣doms! with the heart of Zoilus, the pen of Mae∣vius, and the tongue of Thersites. I was sure he would stick at nothing. The writings of authors
are publick advertisements of their qualifications; and when they profess to live upon scandal, it is as much as to say, that they are ready for every other dirty work, in which we chuse to employ them.—But now for Amelia: if she proves trac∣table, I may forego the use of this villain, who almost makes me hate my triumph, and be ashamed of my revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Mrs. Goodman has informed me that your Ladyship has desired to see me: I wait your com∣mands, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Look you, young woman: I am sensi∣ble how much it is beneath a person of my rank to parley with one of your condition. For once, however, I am content to wave all ceremony; and if you behave as you ought to do, you have nothing to fear, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: I hope I have never behaved otherwise than as I ought to do, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Yes; you have received the visits of Lord Falbridge; you have endeavoured to estrange his affections from me: but, if you encourage him in his infidelity to me, tremble for the consequence: be advised, or you are ruined.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: I am conscious of no guilt, and know no fear, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Come, come, Mrs. Amelia; this high strain is out of character with me. Act over your Clelia, and Cleopatra, and Cassandra, at a proper time; and let me talk in the stile of nature and common sense to you. You have no Lord Fal∣bridge, no weak young nobleman to impose upon at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P:
To impose upon! I scorn the imputation, and am sorry to find that your Ladyship came hi∣ther,
merely to indulge yourself in the cruel plea∣sure of insulting one of the unhappiest of her sex. [weeping.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: You are mistaken; I came hither to con∣cert measures for your happiness, to assist your poverty, and relieve your distress. Leave this house; leave London; I will provide you a retire∣ment in the country, and supply all your wants. Only renounce all thoughts of Lord Falbridge, and never let him know the place of your retreat.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Lord Falbridge! What is Lord Falbridge to me, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: To convince me you have no commerce with him, accept of my proposals.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: No, Madam; the favours which you in∣tend me, I could not receive without blushing. I have no wants but what I can supply myself; no distresses which your Ladyship can relieve; and I will seek no refuge but in my own virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Your virtue! Ridiculous! If you are a woman of virtue, what is the meaning of all this mystery? Who are you? What are you? Who will vouch for your character?

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: It wants no vouchers; nor will I suffer myself to be arraigned like a criminal, till I know by what authority you take upon you to act as my judge.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Matchless confidence! Yes, yes, it is too plain; I see you are the very creature I took you for; a mere adventurer: some strolling prin∣cess, that are perhaps more frugal of your favours than the rest of your sisterhood, merely to enhance the price of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P:
Hold, Madam! This opprobrious lan∣guage is more injurious to your own honour than to ine. I see the violence of your temper, and will leave you. But you may one day know that my birth is equal to your own; my heart is per∣haps
more generous; and whatever may be my situation, I scorn to be dependant on any body; much less on one, who has so mean an opinion of me, and who considers me as her rival. [Exit.

DIV2.P: Her rival! Unparallelled insolence! An open avowal of her competition with me! Yes; I see Spatter must be employed. Her rival! I shall burst with indignation.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Mrs. Goodman! where is Mr. Spatter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: He went out the moment he left your Ladyship. But you seem disordered; shall I get you some hartshorn, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Some poison.—Rival! I shall choak with rage.—You shall hear from me. You, and your Amelia. You have abused me; you have con∣spired against my peace; and be assured you shall suffer for it. [Exit.

DIV2.P: What a violent woman! Her passion makes her forget what is due to her sex and quality. Ha! Mr. Freeport!
My best friend! Welcome to London! When did you arrive from Lisbon?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: But last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: I hope you have had a pleasant voyage?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: A good trading voyage—I have got mo∣ney, but I have got the spleen too.—Have you any news in town?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: None at all, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: So much the better. The less news, the less nonsense.—But what strange lady have you had here? I met her as I was coming up: she rushed by like a fury, and almost swept me down stairs again with the wind of her hoop-petticoat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Ah! jealousy! Jealousy is a terrible passion; especially in a woman's breast, Mr. Free∣port.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Jealousy! Why, she is not jealous of you, Mrs. Goodman?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: No; but of a lodger of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Have you any new lodgers since I left you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Two or three, Sir; the last arrived but to-day; an elderly gentleman, who will see no company.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: He's in the right. Three parts in four of mankind are knaves or fools; and the fourth part live by themselves.—But who are your other lodgers?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: An author and a lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: I hate authors. Who is the lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: She calls herself Amelia Walton; but, I believe that name is not her real one.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Not her real one! Why, sure she is a wo∣man of character?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: A woman of character! She is an angel. She is most miserably poor; and yet haughty to an excess.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Pride and poverty! A sad composition, Mrs. Goodman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P:
No, Sir; her pride is one of her greatest virtues: it consists in depriving herself of almost all necessaries, and concealing it from the world. Tho' every action speaks her to be a
woman of birth and education, she lives upon the work of her own hands without murmur or com∣plaint. I make use of a thousand stratagems to assist her against her will; I prevail on her to keep the money due for rent for her support, and fur∣nish her with every thing she wants at half its prime cost; but if she perceives or suspects these little artifices, she takes it almost as ill as if I had at∣tempted to defraud her. In short, Sir, her un∣shaken virtue and greatness of soul under mis∣fortunes, make me consider her as a prodigy, and often draw tears of pity and admiration from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Ah! women's tears lie very near their eyes. I never cried in my life; and yet I can feel too; I can admire, I can esteem, but what signifies whimpering? Hark ye, Mrs. Goodman! This is a very extraordinary account you give of this young woman; you have raised my curiosity, and I'll go and see this lodger of yours; I am rather out of spirits, and it will serve to amuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, you can't see her; she neither pays visits nor receives them, but lives in the most retired manner in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: So much the better. I love retirement as well as she. Where are her apartments?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: On this very floor, on the other side of the staircase.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: I'll go and see her immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Indeed you can't, Sir. It is im∣possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Impossible! where is the impossibility of going into a room? Come along!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, Mr. Freeport!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: P'shaw! I have no time to lose, I have business half an hour hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: But won't it be rather indelicate, Sir? Let me prepare her first!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Prepare her—With all my heart—But remember that I am a man of business, Mrs. Goodman, and have no time to waste in ceremony and compliment. [Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: No, Polly! If Lord Falbridge comes again, I am resolved not to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Indeed, Madam, he loves you above all the world; I am sure of it; and I verily believe he will run mad, if you don't hear what he has to say for himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: Speak no more of him.

DIV2.P: Mrs. Goodman!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Pardon me, Madam! Here is a gentleman of my acquaintance begs you would give him leave to speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: A gentleman! who is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: His name is Freeport, Madam. He has a few particularities; but he is the best∣harted man in the world. Pray let him come in, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: By no means; you know I receive visits from nobody.

DIV2.P: Bless me! he's here. This is very extraordinary indeed, Mrs. Goodman.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Don't disturb yourself, young woman; don't disturb yourself!

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Mighty free and easy, methinks!

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: Excuse me, Sir; I am not used to receive visits from persons entirely unknown.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Unknown! There is not a man in all London better known than I am. I am a merchant, my name is Freeport; Freeport of Crutched-Friars▪ enquire upon 'Change!

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: Mrs. Goodman! I never saw the gentle∣man before. I am surprised at his coming here.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Pooh! Prithee; Mrs. Goodman knows me well enough. [Mrs. Goodman talks apart with Amelia.] Ay! that's right, Mrs. Goodman. Let her know who I am, and tell her to make herself easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: But the lady does not chuse we should trouble her, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Trouble her? I'll give her no trouble; I came to drink a dish of tea with you; let your maid get it ready, and we will have it here instead of your parlour.—In the mean time I will talk with this lady; I have something to say to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: If you had any business, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Business! I tell you I have very particular business; so sit down, and let's have the tea.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: You shou'd not have followed me so soon, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Pooh, prithee! [Exit Mrs. Goodman.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: This is the oddest man I ever saw in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: Well, Sir, as I see you are a particular acquaintance of Mrs. Goodman—But pray what are your commands for me, Sir! [They sit.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P:
I tell you what, young woman; I am a plain man, and will tell you my mind in an instant. I am told that you are one of the best women in the world; very virtuous, and very poor; I like
you for that: but they say you are excessively proud too, now I don't like you for that, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Free and easy still, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: And pray, Sir, who told you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Mrs. Goodman.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: She has deceived you, Sir; not in regard to my pride perhaps, for there is a certain right pride which every body, especially women, ought to possess! and as to virtue, it is no more than my duty; but as to poverty, I disclaim it; they who want nothing, cannot be said to be poor.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: It is no such thing: you don't speak the truth; and that is worse than being proud. I know very well that you are as poor as Job, that you are in want of common necessaries, and don't make a good meal above once in a fortnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: My mistress fasts for her health, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Hold your tongue hussy! what, are you proud too?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Lord, what a strange man!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: But however, Madam, proud or not proud, does not signify two-pence.—Hark ye, young woman! it is a rule with me (as it ought to be with every good Christian) to give a tenth part of my fortune in charity. In the account of my profits there stands at present the sum of two thousand pounds on the credit side of my books; so that I am two hundred pounds in arrear. This I look upon as a debt due from my fortune to your poverty—Yes, your poverty I say, so never deny it. There's a bank note for two hundred pounds; and now I am out of your debt.—Where the deuce is this tea, I wonder?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I never saw such a man in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: I don't know that I ever was so thoroughly counfounded [apart.]—Sir! [to Free∣port.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: This noble action has surprised me still more than your conversation, but you must excuse my refusal of your kindness; for I must confess, that if I were to accept what you offer▪ I don't know when I should be able to restore it.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Restore it! why who wants you to restore it? I never dreamt of restitution.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: I feel, I feel your goodness to the bottom of my soul; but you must excuse me. I have no occasion for your bounty; take your note, Sir, and bestow it where it is wanted.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Lord, Madam! you are ten times stranger than the gentleman.—I tell you what, Sir; [to Freeport] it does not signify talking; we are in the greatest distress in the world, and if it had not been for the kindness and good-nature of Mrs. Goodman, we might have died by this time. My lady has concealed her distress from every body that was willing and able to relieve her; you have come to the knowledge of it in spite of her teeth; and I hope that you will oblige her, in spite of her teeth, to accept of your generous offer.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: No more, my dear Polly; if you would not have me die with shame, say no more! Return the gentleman his note with my best thanks for his kindness; tell him, I durst not accept of it; for when a woman receives presents from a man, the world will always suspect that she pays for them a the expence of her virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: What's that! what does she say, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P:
Lord, Sir, I hardly know what she says. She says, that when a gentleman makes a young
lady presents, he is always supposed to have a design upon her virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Nonsense! why shou'd she suspect me of an ungenerous design, because I do a generous action?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Do you hear, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: Yes, I hear; I admire; but I must persist in my refusal: if that scandalous fellow Spatter were to hear of this, he would stick at saying nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Eh! what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: She is afraid you should be taken for her lover, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: I for your lover! not I. I never saw you before. I don't love you; so make no scruples upon that account; I like you well enough, but I don't love you at all; not at all, I tell you.—If you have a mind never to see my face any more, good bye t'ye!—You shall never see me any more. If you like I should come back again, I'll come back again;—but I lose time, I have business; your servant! [Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: Stay, Sir! do not leave me without receiving the sincerest acknowledgments of my gratitude and esteem; but, above all, receive your note again, and do not put me any longer to the blush!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: The woman is a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P: Come hither, I beseech you, Mrs. Goodman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Your pleasure, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Amelia.
SP.P:
Here! take this note which that gentleman has given me by mistake; return it to him, I charge you; assure him of my esteem and
admiration; but let him know I need no assistance, and cannot accept it. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Ah! Mr. Freeport! you have been at your old trade. You are always endeavouring to do good actions in secret; but the world always finds you out, you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Well; I don't believe there are two stranger people in England than my mistress, and that gentleman; one so ready to part with money; and the other so unwilling to receive it;—but don't believe her, Sir, for between friends, she is in very great need of assistance I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Indeed I believe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Oh, I have no doubt on't; so I'll tell you what, Mrs. Goodman; keep the note, and supply her wants out of it without her knowledge; and now I think of it, that way is better than t'other.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I never saw such a strange man in my life. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: I shall obey your kind commands, Sir; poor soul! my heart bleeds for her; her virtue and misfortunes touch me to the soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: I have some little feeling for her too; but she is too proud. A fine face; fine figure; well behaved; well bred; and I dare say an excellent heart!—But she is too proud; tell her so, d'ye hear? tell her she is too proud. I shall be too late for my business—I'll see her again soon—It is a pity she is so proud. [Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.
DIV2.P: A YOUNG woman! a native of Scotland! her name Amelia! supposed to be in the greatest distress, and living in total retirement! If fortune should for once smile upon me, and have thrown me into the very same house! I don't know what to think of it; and yet so many un∣common circumstances together recall the memory of my misfortunes, and awaken all the father in my bosom.—I must be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Madam! will you permit me to speak one word to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: [coming forward.] If you please; what is your pleasure, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I presume, Madam, you are the charm∣ing young woman I have heard of?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I have a few charms in the eyes of some folks to be sure, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: And you are a native of Scotland, they tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I am; at your service, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Will you give me leave to ask the name of your family? Who is your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I really don't remember my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Ha! not remember him, do you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: No, Sir; but I have been told that he was—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Who, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: One of the most eminent bakers in Aberdeen, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Oh, I conceive! You live, I suppose, with the young lady I meant to speak to. I mis∣took you for the lady herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: You did me a great deal of honour, I assure you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: But you are acquainted with your mistress's family?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Family, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Ay; who are her parents?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: She comes of very creditable parents, I promise you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I don't doubt it; but who are they? I have particular reasons for enquiring.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Very likely so; but I must beg to be excused, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Of what age is your mistress? you will tell me that at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Oh, as to her age, she don't care who knows that; she is too young to deny her age yet a-while. She is about one-and-twenty, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Precisely the age of my Amelia. [apart.] One-and-twenty, you say? [To Molly.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; and I am about two-and-twenty; there is no great difference between us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P:
[apart.] It must be so; her age, her country, her manner of living, all concur to prove
her mine; my dear child, whom I left to taste of misfortune from her cradle.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: [apart.] What is he muttering, I won∣der; I wish this one-and-twenty has not turned the old gentleman's head.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Let me beg the favour of you to con∣duct me to your mistress: I want to speak with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: She will see no company, Sir; she is in∣disposed; she is in great affliction; and receives no visits at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Mine is not a visit of form or cere∣mony, or even impertinent curiosity; but on the most urgent business. Tell her I am her fellow-countryman.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: What! are you of Scotland too, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I am. Tell her I take part in her af∣flictions, and may, perhaps, bring her some consolation.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: There is something mighty particular about this old gentleman! He has not brought another two hundred pounds, sure! [apart.] Well, Sir; since you are so very pressing, since you say you are our fellow-countryman, if you will walk this way, I'll speak to my mistress, and see what I can do for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I am obliged to you. [Exit Molly.] And now, if I may trust the forebodings of an old fond heart, I am going to throw my arms about my daughter. [Exit.

DIV2.STAGE: [As Sir William follows Molly out on one side, Spatter appears on the other.]
DIV2.P:
There they go! what the deuce can that old fellow and Amelia's maid do together? The slut is certainly conducting him to her mistress! In
less than half an hour I expect that Amelia will be apprehended. In the mean time I must be upon the watch; for, since I have laid the in∣formation, it is high time that I should collect some materials to support it.—Who comes here? Lord Falbridge's valet de chambre: his errand is to Amelia, without doubt; something may be learnt there, perhaps.
Ha! Monsieur La France! your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Serviteur! ver glad to see you, Mon∣sieur Spatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Well; what brings you here? eh, Mon∣sieur La France?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Von lettre, Monsieur.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: A letter to whom?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: From my Lor to Mademoiselle Amelie.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Oh, you're mistaken, Monsieur; that letter is for Lady Alton.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Lady Alton! no, ma foi! it be for Mademoiselle. I am no mistake. Je ne me trompe pas la dessus.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Why, have not you carried several letters from Lord Falbridge to Lady Alton?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Oh, que oui! but dis be for de young laty dat lif here; for Mademoiselle: ml Lor lov her! ma foi; he lov her à la folie.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: And he loved Lady Alton à la folie; did not he?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Oh, que non! he lov her so gently! si tranquilement; ma foi, he lov her à la Françoise.—But now he lov Mademoiselle; he no eat, no sleep, no speak, but Mademoiselle; no tink but of Mademoiselle; quite an oder ting, Monsieur Spat∣ter, quite an oder ting!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Well, well; no matter for that; the letter is for Lady Alton, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Ah! pardonnez moi!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: It is, I assure you; and to convince you of it, see here, Monsieur! Lady Alton has sent you five guineas to pay the postage.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Five guinees! ma foi, I believe I was mistake, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Ay, ay; I told you you were mistaken: and after all, if it should not be for her Ladyship, she will inclose it in another case, and send it to Amelia, and nobody will be the wiser.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Fort bien; ver well; la voila. [gives the letter.] I have got five guinées; I don't care.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Why should you? Where's the harm, if one woman should receive a letter written to ano∣ther? There will be nothing lost by it; for if Amelia don't receive this, she will receive others; and letters of this sort are all alike, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Begar dat is ver true. Adieu, Sir.—I have execute my commission: adieu. Oh! je fais bien mes commissions, moi! [Exit.

DIV2.P:
See the effects of secret-service-money! Intel∣ligence must be paid for; and the bribing couriers is a fair stratagem, by all the laws of war. Shall I break open this letter; or carry it to Lady Alton as it is? No; I'll read it myself, that I may have the credit of communicating the contents. Let me see! [opens the letter and reads.] “Thou dearest, most respectable, and most virtuous of women!” So! this is à la folie, indeed, as Mon∣sieur La France calls it.—“If any consideration could add to my remorse, for the injury I have offered you, it would be the discovery of your real character.” Ah, ah! “I know who you
are. I know you are the daughter of the unhappy Sir William Douglas.”—So, so!—“”Judge then of the tumult of my soul; which is only preserved from the horrors of despair, by the hopes of rendering some service to the father, which may, perhaps, in some measure atone for my behaviour to his too justly of∣fended daughter. Give me leave, this evening, to sue for my pardon at your feet, and to in∣form you of the measures I have taken. In the mean time believe me unalterably yours.

This is a precious paquet, indeed.—Now if I could discover the father too!—His Lordship's visit will be too late in the evening, I fancy; the lady will not be at home; but before she goes, once more to my old trade of eaves-dropping about her apartments! The old gentleman▪ and she are certainly together, and their conversation per∣haps may be curious. At all events, Lady Alton must be gratified. Men of letters never get any thing of their patrons, but by sacrificing to their foibles. [Exit.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir William Douglas and Amelia discovered sitting.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Every word you utter, touches me to the soul. Nothing but such noble sentiments could have supported your spirit under so many misfortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Perhaps it is to my misfortunes that I owe those sentiments; had I been brought up in ease and luxury, my mind, which has learnt for∣titude from distress, might have been enfeebled by prosperity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Thou most amiable of thy sex, I con∣jure thee to hide nothing from me. You say you were born at Aberdeen; you confess that you are derived from one of those unhappy families, who suf∣fered themselves to be so fatally deluded, and drawn from their allegiance to the best of kings. Why, why then, will you not tell me all? Why do you endeavour to conceal your name and family?

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: My duty to my family obliges me to si∣lence. My father's life is forfeited by the sen∣tence of the law; and he owes his existence t this hour to flight or secrecy. He may be in Eng∣land; he may, for aught I know, be in London; and the divulging my name and family might create a fresh search after him, and expose him to new perils. Your conversation, it is true, has in∣spired me with respect and tenderness; but yet you are a stranger to me: I have reason to fear every and one word may undo me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Alas! one word may make us both happy▪ Tell me; of what age were you when your cruel fortune separated you from your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: An infant; so young, that I have not the least traces of him in my memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: And your mother; what became of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: She, as I have often heard, was carried off by a fever, while she was preparing to embark with me, to follow the fortunes of my father▪ He, driven almost to despair by this last stroke o ill fortune, continually shifted his place of resi∣dence abroad; but for some years past, whether by his death, the miscarriage of letters, the infi∣delity of friends, or other accidents, I have n received the least intelligence of him; and now almost begin to despair of hearing of him agai tho' I still persist in my enquiries.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: [rising.] It must be so; it is as I imagined. All these touching circumstances are melancholy witnesses of the truth of it. Yes, my child! I am that unhappy father whom you lost so early; I am that unfortunate husband, whom death and my unhappy fate, almost at the very same period, divorced from the best of wives; I am—I am Sir William Douglas.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Sir William Douglas! have I lived to see my father! then heaven has heard my prayers; this is the first happy moment of my unfortunate life [embracing.]—And yet your presence here fills me with apprehensions; I tremble for your safety, for your life; how durst you venture your per∣son in this kingdom? how can you expose your∣self to the danger of discovery in this town? My whole soul is in a tumult of fear and joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Do not be alarmed, my Amelia; fear nothing; heaven begins to smile upon my ortune. To find thee so unexpectedly, to find thee with a mind so superior to distress, softens the anguish of my past life, and gives me happy mens of the future.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Oh, Sir! by the joy I receive from the embraces of a father, let me conjure you to pro∣vide for your safety! do not expose me to the horror of losing you again; of losing you for ever! Quit this town immediately; every mo∣ment that you remain in it, is at the hazard of your life; I am ready to accompany you to any part of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: My dear child! how I grieve that your youth and virtue should be involved in my mis∣fortunes! Yes, we will quit this kingdom; pre∣pare for your departure, and we may leave Lon∣don this evening.

DIV2.P: Ha! Owen! thou art come at a happy moment. I have found my daughter. This is your young mistress, the paragon of her sex, my dear, my amiable Amelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, this is no time for congratula∣tion. You are in the most imminent danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: What is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: The officers of government are at this instant in the house. I saw them enter; I heard them say they had authority to apprehend some suspected person, and I ran immediately to inform you of your danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Oh, heaven! My father, what will you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: Do not be alarmed, Sir; we are two; we are armed; and we may perhaps be able to make our way through them; I will stand by you to the last drop of my blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Thou faithful creature! Stay, Owen; our fears may betray us; till we are sure we are attacked, let us shew no signs of opposition!

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: My dear mistress! we are ruined; we are undone for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: There are officers of justice in the house; I have heard it; tell me, tell me this instant whom do they seek for?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: For you, Madam; for you; they have a warrant to apprehend you, they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: But they have no warrant to apprehend any body else?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: No, Madam; nobody else; but I will follow you to the end of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: My dear Polly, I did not mean you: retire, Sir; [to Sir William.] For heavens sake leave me to their mercy; they can have no facts against me; my life has been as innocent as unfortunate, and I must soon be released.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: No, my child; I will not leave thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: My child? This is Sir William Dou∣glas then, as sure as I am alive!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Besides, retiring at such a time might create suspicion, and incur the danger we would wish to avoid.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: They will be in the room in a moment; I think I hear them upon the stairs; they would have been here before me, if Mr. Freeport had not come in and stopt them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Courage, my dear Amelia!

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Alas, Sir! I have no terrors but for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: They are here, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Oh, lord! here they are indeed; I am frighted out of my wits.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Goodman, Freeport, and Officer.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: A warrant to seize her? a harmless young woman? it is impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir; if the young lady goes by the name of Amelia Walton, I have a warrant to apprehend her.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: On what account!

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: As a dangerous person.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Dangerous!

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; suspected of disaffection and treasonable practices.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: I am the unhappy object of your search, Sir; give me leave to know the substance of the accusation.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: I cannot tell you particulars, Madam; but information upon oath has been made against you, and I am ordered to apprehend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: But you will accept of bail, Sir; I will be bound for all I am worth in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: In these cases, Madam, bail is not usual; and if ever accepted at all, it is excessively high; and given by persons of very large property, and known character.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Well; my property is large enough, and my character very well known. My name is Freeport.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: I know you very well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: I'll answer for her appearance; I'll be bound in a penalty of five hundred pounds, a thousand, two thousand, or what sum you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: And will you enter into the recognisance immediately?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: With all my heart, come along! [going.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: And are you in earnest, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Ay, to be sure. Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: Because, Sir, I'll venture to say there are but few people that place their money on such securities.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: So much the worse; he who can employ it in doing good, places it on the best security, and puts it out at the highest interest in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I can hardly trust my eyes and ears; who is this benevolent gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: I don't wonder you are surprised at Mr. Freeport's manner of proceeding, Sir; but it is his way. He is not a man of compliment; but he does the most essential service in less time, than others take in making protestations.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Here he is again; heaven reward him!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: So! that matter is dispatched; now to our other affairs! this is a busy day with me.—Look-ye, Sir William; we must be brief; there is no time to be lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: How! am I betrayed then!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Betrayed! no; but you are discovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: What! my master discovered!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: [to Owen] Nay, never clap thy hand to thy sword, old trusty! your master is in danger, it is true; but not from me, I promise you. Go, and get him a post-chaise; and let him pack off this instant; that is the best way of shewing your attachment to him at present.—Twenty years, Sir William, have not made so great an alteration in you, but I knew you the moment I saw you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Harbour no distrust of Mr. Free∣port, Sir; he is one of the worthiest men living.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: I know his worthiness. His behaviour to the officer but this moment, uncommonly generous as it appeared, is not the first testimony he has given me to day, of his noble disposition.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Noble! p'shaw! nonsense!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: [to Freeport] Sir; the kind manner in which you have been pleased to interest yourself in my affairs, has almost as much overpowered me, as if you had surprised me with hostile proceedings. Which way shall I thank you for your goodness to me and my Amelia?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P:
Don't thank me at all; when you are out of danger, perhaps I may make a proposal to you, that will not be disagreeable; at present think of nothing but your escape; for I should not be surprised, if they were very shortly to make you the same compliment, they have paid to Amelia:
and in your case, which is really a serious one, they might not be in the humour to accept of my recognisance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Mr. Freeport is in the right, Sir; every moment of delay is hazardous; let us prevail upon you to depart immediately! Amelia being wholly innocent, cannot be long detained in custody, and as soon as she is released, I will bring her to you, wherever you shall appoint.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Ay, ay, you must be gone directly, Sir! and as you may want ready money upon the road, take my purse! [offering his purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: No, thou truest friend, I have no need of it. With what wonderful goodness have you acted towards me and my unhappy family!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Wonderful! why wonderful? Would not you have done the same, if you had been in my place?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I hope I should.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Well then, where is the wonder of it? Come, come, let us see you make ready for your departure!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Thou best of men!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Best of men? Heaven forbid! I have done no more than my duty by you. I am a man myself; and am bound to be a friend to all man∣kind, you know. [Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV.
DIV2.STAGE: Lady Alton with a letter in her hand, and Spatter.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: THANKS, my good Spatter, many thanks for this precious epistle! more precious at present than one of Ovid, Pliny, or Cicero. It is at once a billet-doux and a state paper; and serves at the same time to convict her of conspiring against me and the publick.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: It is a valuable manuscript, to be sure, Madam; and yet that is but the least half of my discoveries, since I left your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: But is not this half, according to the Grecian axiom, more than the whole, Mr. Spatter?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: When you know the whole, I believe you will think not, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Out with it then! I am impatient to be mistress of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: By intercepting this letter of Lord Fal∣bridge's, your Ladyship sees that we have disco∣vered Amelia to be the daughter of Sir William Douglas.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: True.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: But what would you say, Madam, if I had found out the father himself too?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Sir William Douglas!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Is now in this house, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Nothing more certain. He arrived this morning under a feigned name. I saw him con∣ducted to Amelia's apartment. This raised my suspicion, and I planted myself at her door, with all the circumspection of a spy, and address of a chambermaid. There I overheard their mutual acknowledgments of each other; and a curious interview it was. First they wept for grief; and then they wept for joy; and then they wept for grief again. Their tears, however, were soon in∣terrupted by the arrival of the officer, whose pur∣pose was partly defeated, as you have already heard, by the intervention of Freeport.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Yes, the brute! But that delay was not half so unfortunate, as your discoveries have been happy, Spatter; for my revenge shall now return on them with redoubled fury.—Issue out upon them once more; see what they are about; and be sure to give me immediate notice if Lord Falbridge should come. [Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Stay, Madam. After intercepting the letter, I sent for your Ladyship, that at so critical a juncture, you might be present on the spot: and if you go home again, we shall lose time, which perhaps may be precious, in running to and fro. Suppose you step into the study, till I return. You will find my own answer to my last pam∣phlet, and the two first sheets of the next month's Magazine to amuse you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Planned like a wise general! Do you then go, and reconnoitre the enemy, while I lie here in ambush to reinforce you as soon as there shall be occasion. Do but give the word, we'll make a vigorous sally, put their whole body to rout, and take Amelia and her father prisoners.

DIV2.P: I don't know how it is; but this Amelia here runs in my head strangely. Ever since I saw her, I think of nothing else. I am not in love with her.—In love with her! that's nonsense. But I feel a kind of uneasiness, a sort of pain that—I don't know what to make of it—I'll speak to her father about her.
Well, old true-penny! Have you prepared every thing for Sir William's departure?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: We had need be going, indeed, Sir▪ we are in continual danger while we stay here; who d'ye think lodged the information against Madam Amelia?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Who?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: A person who lodges in this very house, it seems: one Mr. Spatter, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Spatter! how d'ye know?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: I had it from one of the officers who came to apprehend her.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: A dog! I could find in my heart to cut off his ears with my own hands, and save him the disgrace of the pillory.

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: My poor master is always unfortunate. If Lord Brumpton had lived a week longer, Sir William might perhaps have been out of the reach of their malice.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Lord Brumpton?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: Yes, Sir. He was solliciting my master's pardon; but died before he had accomplished his benevolent intentions.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Ha! A thought strikes me. [apart.] Hark ye, friend, [to Owen] does Sir William know the present Lord Brumpton?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: No, Sir. The late lord had no children, or near relations, living; and indeed, he was the only surviving friend of my poor master in the kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Is the chaise at the door?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: Not yet, Sir; but I expect it every moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Run to your master, and desire him not to go till I see him. Tell him I am going out upon his business, and will be back within this hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: I will let him know immediately.—Ah, you're a true friend indeed, Sir. [shaking him ear∣nestly by the hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Ph! prithee!

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: Ah! Heaven preserve you! [Exit.

DIV2.P:
Fare thee well, old honesty!—By the death of Lord Brumpton, without children or near relati∣ons living, as Owen says, the title and estate come to my old friend Jack Brumpton, of Leverpoole; who is of a distant branch; a fortieth cousin, for aught I know; who has past his whole life in a compting-house; and who, a few years ago, no more dreamt of being a Lord, than Grand Signior, or Great Mogul. He has so good a heart, that I believe it is impossible even for a title to corrupt it. I know he is in town; so I'll go to him im∣mediately; acquaint him with the obligation en∣tailed on him, to be of service to Sir William; and make him heir to the benevolence of his pre∣decessor, as well as his wealth and dignity. [going, stops.] Who's here! Mrs. Goodman and Spatter,
as I live! Oh the dog! my blood rises at the vil∣lain. If I don't take care, I shall incur an action of battery for caning the rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: In short, Mr. Spatter, I must beg leave to give you warning, and desire that you would provide yourself with another lodging as soon as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: What now? What the deuce is the mat∣ter with you, Mrs. Goodman?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: I see now the meaning of Lady Al∣ton's recommendation of such a lodger to my house, as well as of her visits to Amelia, and her frequent conferences with you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: The woman is certainly out of her senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: What has been laid to your charge is no joke, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: What! are you there to keep up her back∣hand, Mr. Freeport? What is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: You are found out to be a spy, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: A person who pries into the secrets of families, merely to betray them.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: An informer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: An eaves-dropper.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: A liar.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Right-hand and left! this is too much: what the plague is the matter with you both!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Did not you go and tell that Amelia was a native of Scotland?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Well; and where's the harm of being born in Scotland?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: None; except by your malicious inter∣pretation, rascal; by means of which you made it the ground of an information against her, and were the cause of her being apprehended.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: And you were the cause of her being re∣leased; every man in his way, Mr. Freeport!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Look you, sirrah! you are one of those wretches, who miscall themselves authors; a fel∣low, whose heart, and tongue, and pen, are equal∣ly scandalous; who try to insinuate yourself every where, to make mischief if there is none, and to increase it, if you find any.—But if you fetch and carry like a spaniel, you must be treated like one. I have observed that you are always loitering in the passages; but if I catch you within the wind of a door again, I'll beat you till you are as black as your own ink, sirrah. Now you know my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Very civil and very polite, indeed, Mr. Free∣port. Ha! here comes my friend Lord Falbridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Lord Falbridge your friend? For shame, Mr. Spatter!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Mrs. Goodman, I rejoice to see you. Tell me, how does my Amelia? I have heard of her distress, and flew to her relief. Was she alarmed? Was she terrified?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: Not much, my Lord: she sustained the shock with the same constancy that she endures every other affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: I know her merit; I am too well ac∣quainted with her greatness of soul; and hope it is not yet too late for me to do justice to her vir∣tue.—Go to her, my dear Mrs. Goodman, and tell her, I beg to see her: I have something that concerns her very nearly, to impart to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Good.
SP.P: I will, my Lord. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Oh, Mr. Spatter! I did not see you. What have you got there, Sir? [seeing a paper in his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Proposals for a new work, my Lord! May I beg the honour of your Lordship's name among my list of subscribers?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: With all my heart, Sir. I am already in your debt on another account. [pulling out his purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: To me, my Lord? You do me a great deal of honour; I should be very proud to be of the least service to your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: You have been of great service to me already, Sir. It was you, I find, lodged the in∣formation against this young lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I did no more than my duty, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Yes; you did me a favour, Sir. I con∣sider only the deed, and put the intention quite out of the question. You meant to do Amelia a prejudice, and you have done me a service: for by endeavouring to bring her into distress, you gave me an opportunity of shewing my eagerness to relieve her.—There, Sir! there is for the good you have done, while you meant to make mischief. [giving him a few guineas.] But take this along with it; if you ever presume to mention the name of Amelia any more, or give yourself the least concern about her, or her affairs, I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I am obliged to your Lordship. [bowing.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Be gone, Sir; leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Your most humble servant, my Lord!—So! I am abused by every body; and yet I get money by every body;—egad, I believe I am a much cleverer fellow, than I thought I was. [Exit.

DIV2.P: Alas! I am afraid that Amelia will not see me. What would I not suffer to repair the affront that I have offered her?
Ha! Polly! how much am I obliged to you for sending me notice of Amelia's distress?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Hush, my Lord! Speak lower, for hea∣ven's sake! My mistress has so often forbad me to tell any thing about her, that I tremble still at the thoughts of the confidence I have put in you. I was bewitched, I think, to let you know who she was.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: You were inspired, Polly; heaven in∣spired you to acquaint me with all her distresses, that I might recommend myself to her favour again, by my zeal to serve her, though against her will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: That was the reason I told you; for else I am sure I should die with grief to give her the least uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: But may I hope to see Amelia? Will she let me speak with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: No indeed, my Lord; she is so offended at your late behaviour, that she will not even suffer us to mention your name to her.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Death and confusion! What a wretch have I made myself! Go, Polly, go and let her know that I must speak with her; inform her, that I have been active for her welfare; and have authority to re∣lease her from the information lodged against her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: I will let her know your anxiety, my Lord; but indeed I am afraid she will not see you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: She must, Polly, she must. The ago∣nies of my mind are intolerable; tell her, she must come, if it be but for a moment; or else, in the bitterness of despair, I fear I shall break into her apartment, and throw myself at her feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Lud! you frighten me out of my wits. Have a little patience, and I'll tell my mistress what a taking you are in.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Fly, then! I can taste no comfort, till I hear her resolution. [Exit Molly.
