DIV2.P: How culpably have I acted towards the most amiable of her sex! But I will make her every reparation in my power. The warmth and since∣rity of my repentance shall extort forgiveness from her. By heaven, she comes!—Death! how sensi∣bly does an ungenerous action abase us! I am conscious of the superiority of her virtue, and almost dread the encounter.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: I understand, my Lord, that by your application I am held free of the charge laid against me; and that I am once more entirely at liberty. I am truly sensible of your good offices, and thank you for the trouble you have taken. [going.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Stay, Madam! do not leave me in still greater distraction than you found me. If my zeal to serve you has had any weight with you, it must have inspired you with more favourable dispo∣sitions towards me.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: You must pardon me, my Lord, if I cannot so soon forget a very late transaction. After that all your proceedings alarm me: nay, even your present zeal to serve me creates new suspi∣cions, while I cannot but be doubtful of the mo∣tives from which it proceeds.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Cruel Amelia! for, guilty as ▪I am, I must complain, since it was your own diffidence that was in part the occasion of my crime.—Why did you conceal your rank and condition from me? Why did not you tell me, that you were the daugh∣ter of the unhappy Sir William Douglas?

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Who told you that I was so, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Nay, do not deny it now: it is in vain to attempt to conceal it any longer; it was the main purport of my letter to apprize you of my knowledge of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Your letter, my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Yes; wild as it was, it was the off∣spring of compunction and remorse; and if it conveyed the dictates of my soul, it spoke me the truest of penitents. You did not disdain to read it, sure!

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, I never received any letter from you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Not received any! I sent it this very morning. My own servant was the messenger. What can this mean? Has he betrayed me? At present, suffer me to compensate, as far as possible, for the wrongs I have done you: receive my hand and heart, and let an honourable marriage obliterate the very idea of my past conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: No, my Lord; you have discovered me, it is true: I am the daughter of Sir William Douglas. Judge for yourself then; and think how I ought to look upon a man, who has insulted my distress, and endeavouted to tempt me to disho∣nour my family.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Your justice must acquit me of the in∣tention of that offence, since at that time I was ignorant of your illustrious extraction.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P:
It may be so; yet your excuse is but an aggravation of the crime. You imagined me, per∣haps, to be of as low and mean an origin, as you thought me poor and unhappy. You supposed that I had no title to any dowry but my honour, no de∣pendance but on my virtue; and yet you attempted to rob me of that virtue, which was the only jewel that could raise the meanness of my birth, or sup∣port me under my misfortunes; which, instead of
elieving, you chose to make the pandar to your vile inclinations.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Thou most amiable of thy sex, how I adore thee! Even thy resentment renders thee more lovely in my eyes, and makes thee, if possible, dearer to me than ever. Nothing but our union can ever make me happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Such an union must not, cannot be.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Why? What should forbid it?

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: My father.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Your father! where is he? In whatever part of the world he now resides, I will convey you o him, and he shall ratify our happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Oh lord, Madam! here's the angry lady coming again; she that made such a racket this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: Lady Alton?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Lady Alton! Confusion! Stay, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: No, my Lord; I have endured one af∣front from her already to-day; why should I ex∣pose myself to a second? Her Ladyship, you know, has a prior claim to your attention. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Distraction! I had a thousand things to say to her.—Go, my dear Polly, follow my Ame∣lia! Plead earnestly in my behalf; urge all the tenderest things that fancy can suggest, and return to me as soon as Lady Alton is departed!

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I will, my Lord. Oh lud! here she is, as I am alive! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Abandoned by Amelia! and hunted by this fury! I shall run wild.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: You may well turn away from me; at length I have full conviction of your baseness. I am now assured of my own shame, and your false∣hood. Perfidious monster!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: It is unjust to tax me with perfidy, Madam. I have rather acted with too much since∣rity. I long ago frankly declared to you the utter impossibility of our reconciliation.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: What! after having made your addresses to me? After having sworn the most inviolable affection for me! Oh, thou arch-deceiver▪

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: I never deceived you: when I professed a passion, I really entertained one; when I made my addresses to you, I wished to call you my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: And hat can you alledge in excuse of your falsehood? Have you not been guilty of the blackest perjury?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: The change of my sentiments needs no excuse from me, Madam; you were yourself the occasion of it.—In spite of the torrent of fashion, and the practice of too many others of my rank in life, I have a relish for domestick happiness; and have always wished for a wife, who might render my home a delightful refuge from the cares and bustle of the world abroad. These were my views with you; but, thank heaven, your out∣rageous temper happily betrayed itself in good time, and convinced me that my sole aim in marriage would be frustrated: for I could neither have ben happy myself, nor have made you so.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Paltry evasion! You have abandoned me for your Amelia; you have meanly quitted a person of letters, a woman of rank and condition, for an illiterate vagabond, a needy adventurer.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: The person you mention, Madam, is indeed, the opposite of yourself; she is all meek∣ness, grace, and virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Provoking traitor! You urge me past all sufferance. I meant to expostulate, but you oblige me to invective.—But, have a care! You are not so secure as you suppose yourself; and I may revenge myself sooner than you imagine.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: I am aware of your vindictive disposi∣tion, Madam; for I know that you are more en∣vious than jealous, and rather violent than tender; but the present object of my affections shall be placed above your resentment, and challenge your respect.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Away, fond man! I know that object of your affections better than yourself; I know who she is; I know who the stranger is that ar∣rived for her this morning; I know all: men more powerful than yourself shall be apprised of the whole immediately; and within these two hours, nay, within this hour, you shall see the unworthy object, for which you have slighted me, with all that is dear to her and you, torn away from you perforce. [going.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Ha! how's this? Stay, Madam! Ex∣plain yourself! But one word; do but hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: No; I disdain to hear you: I scorn all explanation. I have discovered the contemptible cause of your inconstancy, and know you to be mean, base, false, treacherous, and perfidious. You have forfeited my tenderness, and be assured you shall feel the effects of my revenge. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P:
What does she mean! The stranger that arrived to-day!—That arrived for my Ame∣lia! Sure it cannot be. [pausing.] Is it possible that—[Re-enter Molly.] Ha, Polly! explain these riddles to me. Lady Alton threatens me; she threatens my Amelia: does she know any
thing? Her fury will transport her to every extra∣vagance: how dreadful is jealousy in a woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Ay, it is a dreadful thing, indeed, my Lord. Well! heaven send me always to be in love, and never to be jealous!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: But she talked of tearing Amelia from me perforce—And then some stranger—She threat∣ens him too: what is it she means?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: What a gentleman that came to Madam Amelia? [alarmed.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Yes, to Amelia; and arrived this very day, she says.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: We are ruined for ever: she means Sir William Douglas!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: The father of my Amelia! Is he here?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord; I was bound to secrecy; but I can't help telling you the whole truth, be∣cause I am sure you will do all in your power to be of service to us.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: You know my whole soul, Polly: this outrageous woman's malice shall be defeated.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Heaven send it may!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Be assured, it shall: do not alarm your mistress; I fly to serve her, and will return as soon as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I shall be miserable till we see you again, my Lord. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: And now, good heaven! that art the protection of innocence, second my endeavours! enable me to repair the affront I have offered to injured virtue, and let me relieve the unhappy from their distresses! [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: OH, my Lord! I am glad to see you returned.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Where is your mistress? [eagerly.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: In her own chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: And where is Sir William Douglas?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: With my mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: And have there been no officers here to apprehend them?

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Officers! No, my Lord. Officers! you frighten me. I was in hopes, by seeing your Lord∣ship so soon again, that there were some good news for us.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Never was any thing so unfortunate. The noble persons, to whom I meant to make ap∣plication, were out of town; nor could by any means be seen or spoken with, till to-morrow morning: and to add to my distraction, I learn't that a new information had been made, and a new warrant issued to apprehend Sir William Douglas and Amelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: Oh dear! What can we do then?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Do! I shall run mad. Go, my dear Polly, go to your Mistress, and Sir William, and inform them of their danger. Every moment is precious, but perhaps they may yet have time to escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I will, my Lord! [going.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Stay! [Molly returns.] My chariot is at the door; tell them, not to wait for any other car∣riage, but to get into that, and drive away imme∣diately.

SP.SPEAKER: Molly.
SP.P: I will, my Lord. Oh dear! I never was so terrified in all my life. [Exit.

DIV2.P: If I can but save them now, we may gain time for mediation. Ha! what noise? Are the officers coming! Who's here?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Milor, Mons. le Duc de—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Sirrah! Villain! You have been the oc∣casion of all this mischief. By your carelessness, or treachery, Lady Alton has intercepted my let∣ter to Amelia.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Lèdy Altón?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Yes, dog; did not I send you here this morning with a letter?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Oui, Milor.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: And did you bring it here, rascal!

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Oui, Milor.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: No, sirrah. You did not bring it; the lady never received any letter from me; she told me so herself; whom did you give it to? [La France hesitates.] Speak, sirrah; or I'll shake your soul out of your body. [Shaking him.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: I giv it to—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Who, rascal?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Monsieur Spatter.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fal.
SP.P: Mr. Spatter?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Oui, Milor; he promis to giv it to Ma∣demoiselle Amelie, vid his own hand.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: I shall soon know the truth of that, Sir, for yonder is Mr. Spatter himself: run, and tell him I desire to speak with him!

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Oui, Milor; ma foi, I vas very near kesh; I never was in more vilain embarras in all my life.

DIV2.P: My letter's falling into the hands of that fellow, accounts for every thing. The contents instructed him concerning Amelia. What a wretch I am! Destined every way to be of prejudice to that vir∣tue, which I am bound to adore.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Monsieur la France tells me▪ that your Lordship desires to speak with me; what are your commands, my Lord? [prtly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: The easy impudence of the rascal puts me out of all patience. [to himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: My Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: The last time I saw you, Sir, you were rewarded for the good you had done; you must expect now to be chastised for your mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Mischief, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; where is that letter of mine, which La France tells me, he gave you to deliver to a young lady of this house?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Oh the devil! [apart.] Letter, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Yes, letter, Sir; did not you give it him, La France?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Oui, Milor!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Y—e—e—s, yes, my Lord; I had the letter of Monsieur La France, to be sure, my Lord; but—but—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P:
But what, sirrah? give me the letter
immediately; and if I find that the seal has been broken, I will break every bone in your skin.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, my Lord! [feeling in his pockets.] I—I—I have not got the letter about me at present, my Lord; but if you will give me leave to step to my apartment, I'll bring it you im∣mediately. [Offering to go.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: [stopping him.] No, no; that will not do, Sir; you shall not stir, I promise you.—Look ye, rascal! tell me, what is become of my letter, or I will be the death of you this instant. [Drawing.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: [kneeling.] Put up your sword, my Lord; put up your sword; and I will tell you every thing in the world. Indeed, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Well, Sir; be quick then!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Lady Alton—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Lady Alton! I thought so; go on, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Lady Alton, my Lord, desired me to pro∣cure her all the intelligence in my power, concern∣ing every thing that past between your Lordship and Amelia.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Well, Sir; what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: A little patience, I entreat your Lordship. Accordingly, to oblige her Ladyship—one must oblige the ladies, you know, my Lord—I did keep a pretty sharp look-out, I must confess: and this morning, meeting Monsieur La France, with a letter from your Lordship in his charge, I very readily gave him five guineas of her Ladyship's bounty-money, to put it into my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Oh Diable! me voila perdu! [aside.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: How! A bribe, rascal? [to La France.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Ah, Milor! [on his knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: At the same price for every letter, he would have sold a whole mail, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Ayez pitiè de moi! [holding up his hands.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Betray the confidence I reposed in you?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: He offered me the letter of his own ac∣cord, my ord.

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: No such ting, en verilè, Milor!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Very true, I can assure your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Well, well; I shall chastise him at my leisure. At present, Sir, do you return me my letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I—I have it not about me, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Where is it, rascal? tell me this instant, or—

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Lèdy Altón—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: [to Spatter.] What! has she got it? speak, Sirrah!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: She has indeed, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Are not you a couple of villains?

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: Oui, Milor. both speak at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: [to Spat.] But hold, Sir! a word more with you! As you seem to be Lady Alton's chief agent, I must desire some further information from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Any thing in my power, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: I can account for her knowledge of A∣melia by means of my letter: but how did she dis∣cover Sir William Douglas?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I told her, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: But how did you discover him yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: By listening, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: By listening?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Yes, by listening, my Lord! let me but once be about a house, and I'll engage to clear it, like a ventilator, my Lord. There is not a door to a single apartment in this house, but I have planted my ear at the keyhole.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: And were these the means, by which you procured your intelligence?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Oh dear! nothing so easy; this is nothing at all, my Lord! I have given an account of the plays in our Journal, for three months together, without being nearer the stage than the pit-pas∣sage; and I have collected the debates of a whole session, fo the Magazine, only by attending in the lobby.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Precious rascal!—Ha! who comes here? Lady Alton herself again, as I live!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: [apart.] The devil she is! I wish I was out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: What! still here, my Lord? still wit∣nessing to your own shame, and the justice of my resentment?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Yes, I am still here, Madam; and sorry to be made a witness of your cruelty and mean∣ness; of your descending to arts, so much beneath your rank; and practices, so unworthy of your sex.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: You talk in riddles, my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: This gentleman shall explain them. Here, Madam! here is the engine of your malice, the instrument of your vengeance, your prime mi∣nister, Mr. Spatter.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: What have I to do with Mr. Spatter?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: To do mischief, to intercept letters, and break them open; to overhear private con∣versations, and betray them; to—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Have you laid any thing of this kind to my charge, Sir? [to Spatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I have been obliged to speak the truth, though much against my will, indeed, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: The truth! thou father of lies, did ever any truth proceed from thee? What! is his Lordship your new patron! A fit Maecenas for thee, thou scandal to the blles lettres!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Your rage at this detection is but a fresh conviction of your guilt.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Do not triumph, monster! you shall still feel the superiority I have over you. The ob∣ject of your wishes is no longer under your protec∣tion; the officers of the government entered the house at the same time with myself, with a war∣rant to seize both Amelia and her father.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Confusion! Are not they gone then? La France! villain! run, and bring me word!

SP.SPEAKER: La Fr.
SP.P: I go, Milor!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Do not flatter yourself with any hopes; they have not escaped; here they are, secured in proper hands.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Death and distraction! now I am com∣pletely miserable.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir William Douglas, Amelia, Owen, and Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Yes, your misery is complete indeed▪ and so shall be my revenge. Oh! your servant, Madam, [turning to Amelia] you now see to what a condition your pride and obstinacy have reduced you. Did not I bid you tremble at the conse∣quences?

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: It was here alone that I was vulnerable. [holding her father's hand,] Oh, Madam, [turning to Lady Alton] by the virtues that should adorn your rank, by the tenderness of your sex, I conjure you, pity my distress! do but release my father; and there are no concessions, however humiliating, which you may not exact from me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Those concessions now come too late, Madam. If I were even inclined to relieve you, at present it is not in my power. [haughtily.] Lord Falbridge perhaps may have more interest.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P:
Cruel, insulting woman! [to Lady Al∣ton.] Do not alarm yourself, my Amelia!—Do not be concerned, Sir! [to Sir William.]
Your enemies shall still be disappointed. Altho' ignorant of your arrival, I have for some time past exerted all my interest in your favour, and by the mediation of those still more powerful, I do not despair of success. Your case is truly a compassi∣onate one; and in that breast, from which alone mercy can proceed, thank heaven, there is the greatest reason to expect it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I am obliged to you for your concern, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Oh, I owe you all this, and much more—But this is no time to speak of my offences, or repentance.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: This is mere trifling. I thought you knew on what occasion you came hither, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: Your reproof is too just, Madam. I attend you, Sir. [to Sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Hold! Let me prevail on you, Sir, [to the Officer] to suffer them to remain here till to∣morrow morning. I will answer for the conse∣quences.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: Pardon me, my Lord! we should be happy to oblige you; but we must discharge the duty of our office.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Distraction!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Come then! we follow you, Sir! Be comforted, my Amelia! for my sake, be comfort∣ed! Wretched as I am, your anxiety shocks me more than my own misfortunes.
SP.STAGE: [As they are going out, Enter Freeport.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Heyday! what now! the officers here again! I thought we had satisfied you this morn∣ing. What is the meaning of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: This will inform you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P:
How's this? Let me see! [reading.] This is to require you—um um—the bodies of William
Ford and Amelia Walton—um—um—suspected per∣sons—um—um—Well, well! I see what this is: but you will accept of bail, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: No, Sir; this case is not bailable, and we have already been reprimanded for taking your recognizance this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Thou good man! I shall ever retain the most lively sense of your behaviour: but your kind endeavours to preserve the poor remainder of my proscribed life are in vain. We must submit to our destiny. [all going.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Hold, hold! one word, I beseech you, Sir! [to the Officer] a minute or two will make no difference—Bail then, it seems, will not do, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Officer.
SP.P: No, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Well, well; then I have something here that will perhaps. [feeling in his pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: What does he mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: No, it is not there.—It is in t'other pocket, I believe. Here, Sir William! [producing a parchment.] Ask the gentleman, if that will not do.—But first of all, read it yourself, and let us hear how you like the contents.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: What do I see! [opening and perusing it.] My pardon! the full and free pardon of my of∣fences! Oh heaven! and is it to you then, to you, Sir, that I owe all this?—Thus, thus let me shew my gratitude to my benefactor!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Get up, get up, Sir William! Thank hea∣ven, and the most gracious of monarchs. You have very little obligation to me, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P: My father restored! Then I am the hap∣piest of women.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: A pardon! I am transported.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: How's this? a pardon!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Under the great seal, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alt.
SP.P: Confusion! what! am I baffled at last then? Am I disappointed even of my revenge?—Thou officious fool! [to Freeport.] May these wretches prove as great a torment to you, as they have been to me! As for thee, [to Lord Fal∣bridge] thou perfidious monster, may thy guilt prove thy punishment! May you obtain the un∣worthy union you desire! May your wife prove as false to you, as you have been to me! May you be followed, like Orestes, with the furies of a guilty conscience; find your error when it is too late; and die in all the horrors of despair! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: There goes a woman of quality for you! what little actions! and what a great soul!—Ha! Master Spatter! where are you going?

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: Following the Muse, Sir! [pointing after Lady Alton.] But if you have any further com∣mands, or his Lordship should have occasion for me to write his Epithalamium—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Peace, wretch! sleep in a whole skin, and be thankful! I would sollicit mercy my∣self. and have not leisure to punish you. Be gone, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Spat.
SP.P: I am obliged to your Lordship—This af∣fair will make a good article for the Evening-Post to-night, however. [Aside, and Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: How happy has this reverse of fortune made e!—But my surprise is almost equal to my joy. May we beg you, Sir, [to Freeport] to in∣form us how your benevolence has effected what seems almost a miracle in my favour?

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: In two words then, Sir William, this happy event is chiefly owing to your old friend, the late Lord Brumpton.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: Lord Brumpton!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P:
Yes; honest Owen there told me, that
his Lordship had been employed in solliciting your pardon. Did not you, Owen?

SP.SPEAKER: Owen.
SP.P: I did, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Upon hearing that, and perceiving the danger you were in, I went immediately to the present Lord Brumpton; who is a very honest fel∣low, and one of the oldest acquaintance I have in the world. He, at my instance, immediately made the necessary application; and guess how agree∣ably we were surprised to hear that the late Lord had already been successful, and that the pardon had been made out, on the very morning of the day his Lordship died. Away went I, as fast as a pair of horses could carry me, to fetch it; and should cer∣tainly have prevented this last arrest, if the warrant to apprehend you, as dangerous persons, had not if∣sued under your assumed names of William Ford and Amelia Walton, against whom the information had been laid. But, however, it has only served to prevent your running away, when the danger was over, for at present, Sir William, thank heaven and his majesty, you are a whole man again; and you have nothing to do but to make a legal appearance, and to plead the pardon I have brought you, to absolve you from all informa∣tions.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Thou honest excellent man! How hap∣pily have you supplied, what I failed to accom∣plish!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Ay, I heard that your Lordship had been busy.—You had more friends at Court than one, Sir William, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: I am overwhelmed with my sudden good fortune, and am poor even in thanks. Teach me, Mr. Freeport, teach me how to make some acknowledgement for your extraordinary genero∣sity!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, Sir William. Not∣withstanding your daughter's pride, I took a liking to her, the moment I saw her.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Ha! What's this!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: What's the matter, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Nothing. Go on, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Why then, to confess the truth, I am afraid that my benevolence, which you have all been pleased to praise so highly, had some little leaven of self-interest in it; and I was desirous to promote Amelia's happiness more ways than one.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Then I am the veriest wretch that ever existed.—But take her, Sir! for I must confess that you have deserved her by your proceedings; and that I, fool and villain that I was, have for∣feited her by mine. [going.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: Hold, hold! one word before you go, if you please, my Lord! You may kill yourself for aught I know, but you shan't lay your death at my door, I promise you. I had a kindness for A∣melia, I must confess; but in the course of my late negotiation for Sir William, hearing of your Lordship's pretensions, I dropt all thoughts of her. It is a maxim with me, to do good wherever I can, but always to abstain from doing mischief.—Now as I can't make the lady happy myself, I would fain put her into the hands of those that can.—So, if you would oblige me, Sir William, let me join these two young folks together, [join∣ing their hands] and do you say Amen to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.P: With all my heart!—You can have no objection, Amelia. [Amelia bursts into tears.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: How bitterly do those tears reproach me! It shall be the whole business of my future life to atone for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Amel.
SP.P:
Your actions this day, and your solicitude for my father, have redeemed you in my good opi∣nion;
and the consent of Sir William, seconded by so powerful an advocate as Mr. Freeport, can∣not be contended with. Take my hand, my Lord! a virtuous passion may inhabit the purest breast; and I am not ashamed to confess, that I had conceived a partiality for you, till your own conduct turned my heart against you; and if my resentment has given you any pain, when I consi∣der the occasion, I must own that I cannot repent it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Fal.
SP.P: Mention it no more, my love, I be∣seech you! You may justly blame your lover, I confess; but I will never give you cause to com∣plain of your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Free.
SP.P: I don't believe you will. I give you joy, my Lord! I give you all joy. As for you, Ma∣dam, [to Amelia] do but shew the world that you can bear prosperity, as well as you have sustained the shocks of adversity, and there are few women, who may not wish to be an Amelia.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Lady Alton in a Passion; Spatter following▪

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: I'LL hear no more, thou Wretch!—At∣tend to Reason!
A Woman of my Rank!—'tis Petty Treason!
Hear Reason, Blockhead! Reason!—what is that?
Bid me wear Pattens, and a high-crown'd Hat!
Won't you be gone?—what want you? what's your View?

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: Humbly to serve the Tuneful Nine in you.—
I must invoke you.—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: I renounce such Things;
Not Phoebus now, but Vengeance sweeps the Strings;
My Mind is Discord all!—I scorn, detest
All Human Kind!—you more than all the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: I humbly thank you, Ma'am,—but weigh the Matter.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: I won't hear Reason! and I hate you, Spatter!
Myself, and ev'ry thing—

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: That I deny;
You love a little Mischief, so do I;
And Mischief I have for you.—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: How, where, when?
Will you stab Falbridge?

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: Yes, Ma'am—with my Pen.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: Let loose, my Spatter, till to Death you've stung 'em,
That green-ey'd Monster, Jealousy, among 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: To dash at all, the Spirit of my Trade is,
Men, Women, Children, Parsons, Lords and La∣dies.
There will be Danger.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: And there shall be Pay.
Take my Purse, Spatter! [Gives it him.

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: In an honest Way.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: Should my Lord beat you—

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: Let them laugh that win!
For all my Bruises, here's Gold-beater's Skin.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: Nay, should he kill you—

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: My Kindness meant
To pay your Merit with a Monument.

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: Your Kindness, Lady, takes away my Breath;
We'll stop, with your good Leave, on this Side Death.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton.
SP.L: Attack Amelia, both in Verse and Prose:
Your Wit can make a Nettle of a Rose.

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: A Stinging-Nettle for his Lordship's Breast;
And to my Stars and Dashes leave the rest.
I'll make 'em miserable, never fear;
Pout in a Month, and part in Half a Year.
I know my Genius, and can trust my Plan;
I'll break a Woman's Heart with any Man.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Alton,
SP.L: Thanks, thanks, dear Spatter! be severe, and bold!

SP.SPEAKER: Spatter.
SP.L: No Qualms of Conscience with a Purse of Gold;
Tho' Pill'ries threaten, and tho' Cralsticks fall,
Your's are my Heart, Soul, Pen, Ears, Bones, and all. [Exit Spatter.

LG.L: Thus to the Winds at once my Cares I scatter—
O 'tis a charming Rascal, this same Spatter!
His precious Mischief makes the Storm subside!
My Anger, thank my Stars! all rose from Pride.
Pride should belong to us alone of Fashion;
And let the Mob take Love, that vulgar Passion!
Love, Pity, Tenderness, are only made
For Poets, Abigails, and Folks in Trade;
Some Cits about their Feelings make a Fuss,
And some are better bred—who live with Us;
How low Lord Falbridge is!—He takes a Wife,
To love, and cherish, and be fix'd for Life!
Thinks Marriage is a comfortable State,
No Pleasure like a vartuous Tete-à-Tete!
Do our Lords Justice, for I would not wrong 'em,
There are not many such poor Souls among 'em.
Our Turtles from the Town will fly with Speed,
And I'll foretell the vulgar Life they'll lead.
With Love and Ease grown fat, they face all Weather,
And, Farmers both, trudge Arm in Arm together:
Now view their Stock, now in their Nurs'ry prattle,
For ever with their Children, or their Cattle.
Like the dull Mill-horse in one Round they keep;
They walk, talk, fondle, dine, and fall asleep;
Their Custom always in the Afternoon—
He bright as Sol, and She the Chaste Full-Moon!
Wak'd with their Coffee, Madam first begins,
She rubs her Eyes, his Lordship rubs his Shins;
She sips, and smirks;—"Next Week's our Wedding-"Day,
"Married seven Years!—and ev'ry Hour (yawns) "more gay!"
"True, Emmy, (cries my Lord)—the Blessing lies,
"Our Hearts in ev'ry Thing (yawns) so sympa∣thize!"
The Day thus spent, my Lord for Musick calls;
He thrums the Bass, to which my Lady squalls;
The Children join, which so delights these Ninnies,
The Brats seem all Guarduccis—Lovatinis.
—What means this Qualm?—Why, sure, while I'm despising,
That vulgar Passion, Envy, is not rising!
O no!—Contempt is struggling to burst out.
I'll give it Vent at Lady Sclpem's Route.
